hints.label: alg-fan-triangulation-area
hints.title: Fan Triangulation for Riemannian Area
hints.content:
161: :label: alg-fan-triangulation-area
162: 
163: **Input:**
164: - Ordered cycle of episodes $C = (e_0, e_1, \ldots, e_{n-1}, e_0)$ with positions $x_i := \Phi(e_i) \in \mathbb{R}^d$
165: - Metric function $g: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ (positive definite)
166: 
167: **Output:** Riemannian area $A_g(C)$ of the 2D surface enclosed by cycle $C$
168: 
169: **Procedure:**
170: 
171: **Step 1: Compute reference point (centroid)**
172: 
173: $$
174: x_c := \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i
175: $$
176: 
177: **Step 2: Evaluate metric at centroid**
178: 
179: $$
180: g_c := g(x_c)
181: $$
182: 
183: **Step 3: For each triangle $T_i = (x_c, x_i, x_{i+1})$, compute edge vectors:**
184: 
185: $$
186: v_1^{(i)} := x_i - x_c, \quad v_2^{(i)} := x_{i+1} - x_c
187: $$
188: 
189: where $x_n := x_0$ (wrap around).
190: 
191: **Step 4: Compute Riemannian inner products:**
192: 
193: $$
194: \begin{aligned}
195: \langle v_1, v_1 \rangle_{g_c} &:= (v_1^{(i)})^T g_c v_1^{(i)} \\
196: \langle v_2, v_2 \rangle_{g_c} &:= (v_2^{(i)})^T g_c v_2^{(i)} \\
197: \langle v_1, v_2 \rangle_{g_c} &:= (v_1^{(i)})^T g_c v_2^{(i)}
198: \end{aligned}
199: $$
200: 
201: **Step 5: Compute triangle area (Gram determinant formula):**
202: 
203: $$
204: A_i := \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\langle v_1, v_1 \rangle_{g_c} \cdot \langle v_2, v_2 \rangle_{g_c} - \langle v_1, v_2 \rangle_{g_c}^2}
205: $$
206: 
207: **Step 6: Sum all triangle areas:**
208: 
209: $$
210: A_g(C) := \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} A_i
211: $$
212: 
213: **Complexity:** $O(n \cdot d^2)$ for $n$ vertices in $d$ dimensions
214: 
215: **Error:** $O(\text{diam}(C)^2)$ where $\text{diam}(C) = \max_{i,j} \|x_i - x_j\|$ (assuming $g$ is $C^2$)

hints.label: thm-fan-triangulation-correct
hints.title: Fan Triangulation Gives Correct Riemannian Area
hints.content:
221: :label: thm-fan-triangulation-correct
222: 
223: Let $C = (x_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, x_0)$ be a simple closed curve in $(\mathcal{X}, g)$ bounding a simply-connected region $\Sigma \subset \mathcal{X}$.
224: 
225: Assume:
226: 1. $\Sigma$ is nearly planar (small geodesic curvature)
227: 2. $\text{diam}(\Sigma) \ll R_g$ where $R_g$ is the radius of curvature of $(\mathcal{X}, g)$
228: 3. Metric $g$ is $C^2$ on $\Sigma$
229: 
230: Then the fan triangulation algorithm {prf:ref}`alg-fan-triangulation-area` computes:
231: 
232: $$
233: A_g(C) = \text{Vol}_g(\Sigma) + O(\text{diam}(\Sigma)^3)
234: $$
235: 
236: where $\text{Vol}_g(\Sigma) = \int_\Sigma dV_{g_\Sigma}$ is the true Riemannian area.
237: 
238: **Proof idea:**
239: 1. Each triangle area $A_i$ approximates the Riemannian area of the corresponding region
240: 2. Using $g_c$ (metric at centroid) instead of variable $g(x)$ introduces error $O(\|\nabla g\| \cdot \text{diam}^2)$

221: :label: thm-fan-triangulation-correct

224: 
225: Assume:
226: 1. $\Sigma$ is nearly planar (small geodesic curvature)
227: 2. $\text{diam}(\Sigma) \ll R_g$ where $R_g$ is the radius of curvature of $(\mathcal{X}, g)$
228: 3. Metric $g$ is $C^2$ on $\Sigma$
229: 
230: Then the fan triangulation algorithm {prf:ref}`alg-fan-triangulation-area` computes:
231: 
232: $$
233: A_g(C) = \text{Vol}_g(\Sigma) + O(\text{diam}(\Sigma)^3)
234: $$
235: 
236: where $\text{Vol}_g(\Sigma) = \int_\Sigma dV_{g_\Sigma}$ is the true Riemannian area.
237: 
238: **Proof idea:**
239: 1. Each triangle area $A_i$ approximates the Riemannian area of the corresponding region

241: 3. Summing $n$ triangles accumulates error $O(n \cdot \text{diam}^3)$

hints.label: def-plaquette-area-gauge
hints.title: Plaquette Area in Lattice Gauge Theory
hints.content:
248: :label: def-plaquette-area-gauge
249: 
250: In the lattice QFT framework ({doc}`08_lattice_qft_framework.md`), a **plaquette** $P$ is an elementary closed loop formed by:
251: 
252: $$
253: P = (e_{i_0} \xrightarrow{\text{CST}} e_{i_1} \xleftarrow{\text{IG}} e_{j_1} \xleftarrow{\text{CST}} e_{j_0} \xrightarrow{\text{IG}} e_{i_0})
254: $$
255: 
256: **Four vertices:**
257: - $x_{i_0}, x_{i_1}, x_{j_1}, x_{j_0}$ (positions of the four episodes)
258: 
259: **Riemannian area:** Apply fan triangulation:
260: 
261: $$
262: A_g(P) = \text{FanTriangulation}([x_{i_0}, x_{i_1}, x_{j_1}, x_{j_0}], g)
263: $$
264: 
265: **Use in Wilson action:** From {prf:ref}`def-wilson-action-lattice` in {doc}`08_lattice_qft_framework.md`:
266: 
267: $$
268: S_{\text{Wilson}}[\mathcal{F}] = \sum_{P \in \text{Plaquettes}} \left(1 - \text{Re}[W[P]]\right) \cdot A_g(P)
269: $$
270: 
271: where $W[P]$ is the Wilson loop around plaquette $P$.
272:

245: ### 2.2. Riemannian Area for Plaquettes in Lattice QFT
246: 
247: :::{prf:definition} Plaquette Area in Lattice Gauge Theory
248: :label: def-plaquette-area-gauge
249: 
250: In the lattice QFT framework ({doc}`08_lattice_qft_framework.md`), a **plaquette** $P$ is an elementary closed loop formed by:
251: 
252: $$
253: P = (e_{i_0} \xrightarrow{\text{CST}} e_{i_1} \xleftarrow{\text{IG}} e_{j_1} \xleftarrow{\text{CST}} e_{j_0} \xrightarrow{\text{IG}} e_{i_0})
254: $$
255: 
256: **Four vertices:**
257: - $x_{i_0}, x_{i_1}, x_{j_1}, x_{j_0}$ (positions of the four episodes)
258: 
259: **Riemannian area:** Apply fan triangulation:
260: 
261: $$
262: A_g(P) = \text{FanTriangulation}([x_{i_0}, x_{i_1}, x_{j_1}, x_{j_0}], g)
263: $$
264: 
265: **Use in Wilson action:** From {prf:ref}`def-wilson-action-lattice` in {doc}`08_lattice_qft_framework.md`:
266: 
267: $$
268: S_{\text{Wilson}}[\mathcal{F}] = \sum_{P \in \text{Plaquettes}} \left(1 - \text{Re}[W[P]]\right) \cdot A_g(P)
269: $$
270: 
271: where $W[P]$ is the Wilson loop around plaquette $P$.
272: 
273: **Physical interpretation:**
274: - Larger $A_g(P)$: Stronger penalty for non-trivial holonomy

hints.label: prop-curvature-from-area-defect
hints.title: Curvature from Area Defect
hints.content:
281: :label: prop-curvature-from-area-defect
282: 
283: For a plaquette $P$ with Euclidean area $A_{\text{Euclid}}(P)$ and Riemannian area $A_g(P)$, define the **area ratio**:
284: 
285: $$
286: r_A(P) := \frac{A_g(P)}{A_{\text{Euclid}}(P)}
287: $$
288: 
289: Then:
290: 
291: $$
292: r_A(P) \approx 1 + \frac{1}{6} R_{\text{scalar}} \cdot A_{\text{Euclid}}(P) + O(A^2)
293: $$
294: 
295: where $R_{\text{scalar}}$ is the scalar curvature at the plaquette centroid.
296: 
297: **Interpretation:**
298: - $r_A > 1$: Positive curvature (sphere-like, "stretched")
299: - $r_A < 1$: Negative curvature (hyperbolic, "compressed")
300: - $r_A \approx 1$: Flat (Euclidean geometry)
301: 
302: **Use:** Measure curvature empirically by computing $r_A$ for plaquettes.
